normalised: Think of builder reviews like relying on wedding gossip. Some is true, some is exaggerated, and some is just plain fabricated. Many "reviews" are cleverly disguised marketing by the builder themselves, especially on their own website. So, how do you sift through the noise?

normalised: Firstly, look for reviews on independent platforms like Magicbricks or NoBroker. Read reviews across multiple sites – a consistent pattern (good or bad) is more trustworthy. Pay attention to specific details. A generic "Great builder!" is less helpful than "Shobha Developers delivered on time (promised possession date was fifteenth august two thousand and twenty four) and the quality is excellent, even though the clubhouse wasn’t ready by then." Look for mentions of things like delays, hidden costs (like registration charges or parking fees), construction quality issues (cracks, leakages, etcetera), and the builder's responsiveness to complaints.

normalised: Also, connect with current residents of their existing projects. Visiting the site and talking to people directly will give you more realistic feedback than any online review. Maybe visit one of their older projects on a Sunday afternoon around zero three zero zero P M when people are generally home. Finally, check if they are R E R A compliant and if there have been any consumer court cases filed against them. Good luck with your property search! You got this!
